citation.biblCit: Population Research Laboratory, 2015, "Alberta Survey, 2006", https://doi.org/10.7939/DVN/10550, UAL Dataverse, V6

AuthEnty.affiliation: Department of Sociology, University of Alberta

stdyInfo.abstract: The 2006 Alberta Survey (AS) was the 18th annual provincial survey administered by the Population Research Laboratory (PRL). This omnibus survey of households in the province of Alberta continues to enable academic researchers, government departments, and non-profit organizations to explore a wide rang e of research topics in a structured research framework and environment.

sumDscr.universe: The target population designated for telephone interviewing was all pesons 18 years of age or older who, at the time of the survey, were living in a dwelling unit in Alberta that could be contacted by direct dialing. From this population, three samples were drawn to cover Alberta: Edmonton Metropolitan Area, Calgary Metropolitan Area, and the rest of the province.

dataColl.sampProc: SAMPLING DESIGN Main Features of Design: a. Province of Alberta was delineated into three areas for telephone interviewing. (1) Edmonton Metropolitan Area (2) Calgary Metropolitan Area (3) Remainder of the Province (Other Alberta). b. Two-stage selection process. (1) Selection of households. (2) Selection of respondent within each household. To permit the analysis of each area as a separate entity, a minimum sample size of 400 or more for each area of the province was instituted. The target population designated for telephone interviewing was all persons 18 years of age or older who, at the time of the survey, were living in a dwelling unit in Alberta that could be contacted by direct dialling. From this population, three samples were drawn to cover Alberta: Edmonton Metropolitan Area, Calgary Metropolitan Area, and the rest of the province. A Random-Digit Dialling approach was used to ensure that respondents had an equal chance to be contacted whether or not their household was listed in a telephone directory. The PRL has developed a database of five-digit telephone banks (e.g. 403/780-xxx-xx) covering all of Alberta. The 2006 Alberta Survey sample was drawn from this provincial database by using a computer program to select, with replacement, a simple random sample of banks for each area and appending a random number between 00 and 99 to each number selected. Duplicate telephone numbers generated were purged from the computer list. Within the household, one eligible person was selected as the respondent. The mean length of the interview in the 2006 survey was 27.8 minutes. A respondent within each household was selected on the basis of gender using the following selection guidelines to ensure an equal selection of male and female participants. a. He/she must be 18 years of age or older. b. If an adult male answers the phone and is willing to be interviewed, he is the respondent. c. If an adult female answers the phone and there is an adult male present who is willing to be interviewed, interview the male. If the male is not willing to be interviewed, and the female is willing, interview the female. d. If an adult female answers the phone and there is no adult male present, choose her as the respondent.
dataColl.weight: The weighting factors used for the 2006 survey are as follows: Edmonton Metropolitan: 0.949299 Calgary Metropolitan: 0.991455 Other Alberta: 1.059497.

var.name: a1
var.labl: Do you believe that our climate has been changing in recent history?

var.name: a3
var.labl: What are some of the potential impacts of climate change that you have heard about?

var.name: a4
var.labl: Please tell me how much you agree with the statement: 'climate change will have a significant impact in Alberta.'

catgry.labl: N/A-did not say yes to belief in climate change a1
N/A-did not say yes to belief in climate change a1

var.name: a7
var.labl: How do you view the Government of Canada's position on reducing the impact of climate change?

catgry.labl: It is not putting enough resources into it

var.name: d2
var.labl: How necessary is forensic science in order to conclude a person's guilt of a violent crime? For example, homicides, assaults and sexual assaults.

var.name: d3
var.labl: How necessary is forensic science to conclude a person's guilt of a non-violent crime? For example, theft, motor vehicle theft, or burglary.

var.name: d4
var.labl: How necessary is DNA analysis, a specific form of forensic science, to conclude a person's guilt of a violent crime?

var.name: d5
var.labl: How necessary is DNA analysis to conclude a person's guilt of a non-violent crime?

var.name: d6

var.name: d7
var.labl: In general, how accurate do yo think DNA analysis usually is?

var.name: d9

var.name: d10
var.labl: In the CSI shows, how accurately do you think they depict a crime scene investigator's forensic science knowledge and expertise?

var.name: d11
var.labl: What percentage of your knowledge about forensic science came from the CSI TV shows?

var.name: d12
var.labl: Imagine you are sitting on a jury. How applicable do you think your forensic science knowledge is to conclude a person's guilt?

var.labl: For me, regular physical activity will keep me healthy.

var.name: e13

var.name: e14

var.name: e15
var.labl: I have easy access to places where I can get physical activity.

var.name: e16

var.name: e17
var.labl: Many shops, stores, or other places to buy things I need are within easy walking distance of my home.

var.name: e18
var.labl: There are sidewalks on most of the streets in my neighbourhood.

var.name: e19
var.labl: In and around my neighbourhood, there are facilities for bicycling such as special bicycle lanes, bicycle paths, and shared use trails for cyclists and pedestrians.

var.name: e20
var.labl: My neighbourhood has several free or low cost recreation facilities, such as parks, walking trails, bike paths, playgrounds, and recreation centres.

var.name: e21
var.labl: The crime rate in my neighbourhood makes it unsafe to go for walks at night.

var.name: e22
var.labl: There is so much traffic on the streets that it makes it difficult or unpleasant to walk in my neighbourhood.

var.name: e23
var.labl: I see many people engaging in physical activity in my neighbourhood.

var.name: e24
var.labl: There are many interesting things to look at while walking in my neighborhood.
